text: it's barely daylight when andreas Amador
goes to work he's an earth scape artist
which means he spends his days on the
beach raking the sand he lets his
imagination run wild
creating geometric patterns sometimes
they're huge sometimes not but they're
all very different
I would say my biggest inspiration is
nature and the patterns that I see
around me but I'm trying to translate
the world that I see and try to
understand it so it almost feels like a
scientific pursuit on some level he
rakes the beach to bring different
colors of sound to the surface and by
blending broad and narrow strokes he
creates patterns that are really quite
stunning it's difficult for him to see
if his designs are working from the
ground so he mounts a camera on a
quadcopter which hovers above the design
and takes pictures beachgoers love his
work and often travel miles to see it
but some visitors might not be quite so
welcome Andreas used to be an
environmental scientist but he gave it
all up to follow his dream and still
can't quite believe his luck it has
opened more doors and made more things
possible then that I could never could
have dreamed up before I never would
have thought that I could make be
linking a living raking in the sand his
work may disappear forever when the tide
comes in but that doesn't worry andreas
Amador it just means he has a blank
canvas to rake over in the morning
Wendy Urquhart BBC news
